topic: TrustGen Model Selection and Evaluation Principles

  entities:
    Llama 3|Model
    Llama 3.1|Model
    Vicuna|Model
    OpenAI|Organization
    Meta|Organization
    Google|Organization
    Anthropic|Organization
    Dall-E 3|Model
    Table 5|Report

  proposition: The authors follow two key principles for model selection in their evaluation.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    authors|FOLLOWS|model selection principles

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: Latest and Cutting-edge Models: The model selection prioritizes the most recent and powerful models available.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    model selection|PRIORITIZES|recent and powerful models

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The authors choose models like Llama 3 and Llama 3.1 as they represent the latest advancements.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    Llama 3|REPRESENTS|latest advancements
    Llama 3.1|REPRESENTS|latest advancements

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The Vicuna series is not selected because its current performance lags behind newer models.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    Vicuna|PERFORMANCE|lags behind newer models

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The selection focuses on state-of-the-art models to capture the frontier of generative foundation model capabilities.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    selection|FOCUSES_ON|state-of-the-art models
    models|CAPTURES|generative foundation model capabilities

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: Coverage of Major Model Developers: The selection includes models from a diverse range of mainstream developers.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    selection|INCLUDES|models from diverse developers

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The selected models come from leading organizations such as OpenAI, Meta, Google, and Anthropic.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    none

    entity-entity relationships:
    OpenAI|DEVELOPS|models
    Meta|DEVELOPS|models
    Google|DEVELOPS|models
    Anthropic|DEVELOPS|models

  proposition: This approach enables a comprehensive comparison of diverse approaches to generative foundation model development.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    approach|ENABLES|comprehensive comparison

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The selected models span multiple categories including Text-to-Image (T2I), Large Language Models (LLM), and Vision-Language Models (VLM).
    entity-attribute relationships:
    models|SPANS|multiple categories
    models|INCLUDES|Text-to-Image
    models|INCLUDES|Large Language Models
    models|INCLUDES|Vision-Language Models

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The models are evaluated across various trustworthiness dimensions using different implementation strategies.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    models|EVALUATED_BY|trustworthiness dimensions
    models|USES|implementation strategies

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: Implementation strategies include Dataset Pool Maintainer, Web-Browsing Agent, Model Generation, and LLM-Based Paraphrasing.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    strategies|INCLUDES|Dataset Pool Maintainer
    strategies|INCLUDES|Web-Browsing Agent
    strategies|INCLUDES|Model Generation
    strategies|INCLUDES|LLM-Based Paraphrasing

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: Text-to-image models like Dall-E 3 have emerged as powerful generative models capable of synthesizing high-quality images from textual descriptions.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    Dall-E 3|CAPABILITY|synthesizing high-quality images
    Dall-E 3|TYPE|text-to-image model
    Dall-E 3|DESCRIPTION|powerful generative model

    entity-entity relationships:
    none

  proposition: The complete list of selected models is detailed in Table 5 of the original document.
    entity-attribute relationships:
    models|LISTED_IN|Table 5

    entity-entity relationships:
    none
